climbs.name: Twins
climbs.fa: Todd Swain and Kip Knapp, Sept. 1989

content.description: A low quality, grainy fist crack
content.location: leftmost crack on the northeast face

climbs.name: Sore Loserman
climbs.fa: Steve Gerberding, Cal Gerberding, Mark Bowling, 10/2000

content.description:
Start up short cracks to connect to a prominent right-slanting crack that leads up to a high alcove.  Continue up and right to a roof with a dangling down-pointing flat loaf.  Surmount that roof onto a welcoming juggy slot that finishes up easier terrain to the top.

Note: the nice edge above the high alcove and halfway to the roof felt flexy, so pull down, not out.  Shouldn't have to crank full body weight onto that anyway.  Wild moves to reach the roof using features around you -- will just leave it at that to not ruin the surprise and fun.  Fantastic getting to and also over the roof.

Some might deduct a star due to the hollow or sandy bits here and there.  I won't hold that against it.  The roof is excellent.  A good climb once it cleans up.  Well worth the moderate scrambling and short walk from the road.
content.location: Right of Raunchy Bung and left of the Boomerang dihedral ramp.  Walk off by scrambling down to climber's right, involving a few exposed 5.easy face moves, to touch down on the elevated notch btwn the Lost and the Found formations.

climbs.name: Raunchy Bung
climbs.fa: Mark Senyk, Eileen Coleman, Tucker Tech, 1/2000

content.description:
Scramble up to the alcove start.  Squeeze in and up.  Fun jugs will soon appear, leading up to a high grainy ledge.  Continue up the left slot for better pro (rightside one very grainy initially).  The upper part of the rightside slot would come into reach near the top.  Pull up into a big gap that recesses back.  Continue up the rightside taller juggy face with no pro (hence the PG13) and go all the way back (toward the road) to reach the old rap bolts with tats and biner on that summit's NE arete.

The anchor bolts feel solid but are very old.  Not sure how rusty underneath.  The hangers are the early rounded ones that aren't as thick as modern hangers.  No rap rings or chains.  Just one worn thin cord and another dilapidated one that a party prob threaded the rope directly through and rapped on, then pulled the rope across those cords and off.  We added an additional sling and donated a booty biner.  This anchor could use an upgrade.
content.protection: Pro to 3.5", bolted rap hangers with slings and one biner.
content.location: Right of two alcoves to climber's right of Bung Hole marks the start of Raunchy Bung, to top out on the highest isolated summit.  Its bolted anchor with rap slings can NOT be accessed from the topouts of nearby routes.  Better to do this route last, as the rap touches down facing the road at near ground level, and other(s) could carry rappeller's stuff back down the approach gully.

content.description: This crack route has very poor rock.
content.location: near the center of the northeast face

content.description: Route begins with 4 bolts, crux between bolts 2 and 3. Clipping the 3rd bolt can be dicey. Very fun engaging movement on side pulls with poor feet define the hardest moves. The route climbs on and on for ever through easier (but thoughtful) terrain after those 4 bolts, cams and stoppers will take you to the summit.
content.protection: 4 QDs, cams from fingers to hands, bolted anchor.
content.location: Obvious bolt line to the right of the easier crack lines on the wall.

content.description: Scamper up to the shorter right-slanting crack right of Bummerang. Near the top, finish by reaching further up to another right-slanting finger rail. Possible also to hand traverse along the main diagonal all the way to its end, but with marginal and somewhat runout gear. Gear anchor at same spot on the high shoulder as Bummerang.
content.location: Walk off by scrambling further back and then downward to climber's right.

content.description: This climb starts about twenty feet right of "Twins". Climb up and right to a left-leaning thin crack and crack through the headwall above.

Right slanting crack up and right from Boomerang.  Walk off by scrambling down to climber's right, involving a few exposed 5.easy face moves, to touch down near the top of the notch btwn the Lost and Found formations.
content.location: Located on the protruding right upper side of the face, near top of the notch btwn the Lost and the Found formations.  Two left-slanting cracks are seen.  Comes Around is the rightside crack.  The leftside crack comes down to the arete but peters out and doesn't reach down to the base.

content.description: Chimney up a wide slot on the far left end of the upper main face.  Transfer onto unprotected face to reach a lone bolt.  Continue up to reach a short right-slanting crack that tops out onto a low shoulder on that far left end.  Scramble off to climber's left.
content.protection: 1 bolt plus small to med gear, gear anchor.
content.location: Leftmost route on the upper west main face, with a visible lone bolt.

climbs.name: Bummerang
climbs.fa: Tucker Tech, Mark Senyk, Eileen Coleman, 1/2000

content.description: Start up cracks in the middle of the lower, sandy, lighter-colored outcrop down and left from the main west face (the dark wall further back and higher) to gain a right slanting crack that tops out on a high shoulder.
content.location: Walk off by scrambling further back and then downward to climber's right.

content.description: This climb is better than the routes on the northeast face.  It's a fairly nice dihedral with a committing lieback at the crux; somewhat runout
content.location: large ramp on the west face
